thread.title: Aldinga beach tragedy: Woman drows while trying to save child south of Adelaide - Yahoo7
thread.title_full: Aldinga beach tragedy: Woman drows while trying to save child south of Adelaide - Yahoo7

author: Aap On February
title: Aldinga beach tragedy: Woman drows while trying to save child south of Adelaide - Yahoo7
text:
Share Aldinga beach tragedy: Woman drows while trying to save child south of Adelaide - Yahoo7 A woman has died after being pulled from the water at Aldinga Beach in Adelaide's south. Close Australia set to sweat through heatwave UP NEXT VIDEO Australia set to sweat through heatwave 
Emergency services were called to the beach, in Adelaide's south, at about 6.40pm on Thursday. 
It is understood the 28-year-old woman was swept out to see by a rip while on an inflatable pool toy. Emergency services were not able to revive a woman who drowned at an Adelaide beach reportedly while trying to save a child. Source: 7 News 
It has been reported that she was trying to save a child who had floated out to sea on the toy. 
The woman was unconscious when brought from the water and could not be revived, police said. 
The tragedy unfolded as hundreds of people headed to the popular beach to seek relief from the heat. The tragedy occurred as crowds flocked to the beach for relief from the heat. Source: 7 News Efforts to try to revive the woman did not work and she died on the beach. Source: 7 News 
Hemi Vaneyk was at the beach with his partner, her cousin and other friends when he saw several people had been swept out to sea on inflatable toys. 
Mr Vaneyk and his partner's cousin paddled out to try to save the people in distress. 
"There was two floats, one float had two people and one of them was holding onto the lady that had drowned," Mr Vaneyk said. 
The people in distress clung to his kayak as he frantically paddled them in to shore. Hemi Vaneyk attempted to save the woman who eventually drowned on a beach south of Adelaide. 
"There was people sort of in the shallow waters, waiting to be close enough to take her off us. 
"Then we all jumped out of the kayak, pulled the float in with the lady and then people jumped on trying to do CPR." 
Authorities are now urging people to not use pool toys at the beach following the tragic accident. 
A warning sign to beware of strong currents is clearly posted on the beach a couple of hundred metres from where the woman died. 
Mr Vaneyk's partner Beth Corfield has paid tribute to his efforts on Facebook. Mr Vaneyk's partner Beth Corfield has commended his efforts to save the woman. Photo: Facebook 
"I am so so so proud of my amazing partner Hemi Vaneyk and cousin Warren J Button as they went out to help sensing that something wasn't right. 
"It takes a lot of courage to do what you guys did today and you guys should be extremely proud of yourselves, although it wasn't the ideal outcome we were hoping for, you guys did all that you could do!" 
She added that her thoughts go out to the family of the deceased woman.
